title: UK weather forecast latest hot Met Office forecast long range forecast heat September 2018
story: The mercury will rocket this weekend with 30C (86F) temperatures threatening to bake parts of the country next week.Unrelenting hot weather will ramp up the thermostat through September and possibly beyond, experts say.Southern Britain will see the best of the sunshine and drier weather with Scotland and northern England generally staying cooler and wetter.Britain is likely to stay warmer than normal through the next three months, according to the latest government long-range outlook.                BBC Weather: Cold snap ENDS as UK to see temperatures ROCKET again                BBC Weather forecast: Temperatures to DROP before heatwave returnsRare anomalies in ocean waters around the UK will drive a tendency towards above-average temperatures until December, the Met Office said in its three-month contingency planner.North Atlantic waters are currently cooler than normal while closer to Britain they are warmer than would be expected at this time of year.A Met Office spokesman said: &ldquoSea surface temperatures across much of the northern North Atlantic Ocean remain below average.&ldquoThis pattern moderately increases the chances of high pressure over Northern Europe during September.&ldquoIn early autumn, high pressure is often associated with above-average temperatures.&ldquoMeanwhile, sea surface temperatures close to the UK continue to be well above average following the hot summer.UK weather forecast: The heatwave could last until Christmas (Image: NETWEATHER.TV)&ldquoThis also increases the chances of above-average UK temperatures, mainly in the early part of the outlook period.&ldquoFor September and for September-October-November as a whole, above-average temperatures are more likely than below-average temperatures.UK weather charts show temperatures rising across southern Britain this week before hitting the mid 20Cs by the weekend.Parts of the country will nudge the high 20Cs during the start of next week although some forecasters predict higher temperatures.Exacta Weather&rsquos James Madden said: &ldquoHigh pressure is going to rebuild across the country this week and this will start leading to a gradual transition to warmer temperatures.&ldquoWe expect this set up to bring more in the way of sunshine and by the weekend we could be pushing the 30C (86F) mark in parts of Britain.                BBC Weather: Cold snap ENDS as UK to see temperatures ROCKET againUK weather forecast: Southern Britain will see the best of the sunshine  (Image: NETWEATHER.TV)&ldquoSome models suggest temperatures could rise even higher which means we could be looking at some record-breaking heat during the start of September.&ldquoThis is not going to be a flash in the pan heatwave, there are some indications that September is looking pretty warm throughout.&ldquoThere are likely to be a number of significant heat bursts through the start of autumn with warmer than normal weather possibly holding out into mid-October or even beyond.&ldquoWe have certainly not seen the back of summer with a lot more in the way of heat to come.WeatherAction forecaster Piers Corbyn agreed parts of Britain will stay warmer than usual through the coming month.High pressure stretching up from the tropical Azores Islands in the Atlantic will push temperatures up from the weekend, he added.UK weather forecast: Britain is likely to stay warmer than normal through the next three months (Image: NETWEATHER.TV)He said: &ldquoThere will be a nationwide split when it comes to the warmer weather, this weekend we expect cooler, showery conditions in the north while it will be hotter in the south.&ldquoWe have an Azores High extending towards Britain and this will help temperatures to rise in southern parts of the country.&ldquoLooking further ahead into the next month there are indications the south will largely remain warmer than average, Scotland and the north will see more in the way of cooler, wetter weather.Warmer weather will start creeping into northern Britain through the latter part of September, according to the Met Office.Spokeswoman Nicola Maxey said high pressure will build after the weekend pushing temperatures into the mid-20Cs.However it will lead to clear skies and some chilly nights which could cause the odd air frost, she added.She said: &ldquoThere is a chance that next week we will start to see high pressure build from the Azores and this will cause a rise in temperatures.&ldquoSettled conditions are more likely in the south with more chance of rain and cooler temperatures in Scotland and northern England.UK weather forecast: Temperatures could push 28C next week (Image: NETWEATHER.TV)UK weather forecast: Warm air will come in from the Continent (Image: NETWEATHER.TV)&ldquoThis pattern of high pressure is expected to set in through the rest of September and later in the month we could see increasing temperatures spread further north.&ldquoThere may be some short-lived unsettled cooler spells in this period, and with high pressure in charge there will be some cooler nights due to the clearer skies.&ldquoParts of the country could see the odd air frost.Britons in southern and eastern regions will get the first taste of the warmer weather this weekend with thermometers poised to nudge the mid-20Cs on Sunday.Further north the mercury will hover around the 20C (68F) mark with parts of Scotland expected to drop to low single figures overnight this week.Thermometers in southern England are expected to nudge the upper 20Cs by the end of next week with highs of 23C (73.4F) forecast further north.Long-range temperature models suggest parts of Britain will remain slightly warmer than average through to the end of the year.Netweather forecaster Paul Michaelwaite said: &ldquoInto next week, with high pressure starting to take control, fine, often sunny weather is set to become the norm.Some experts say a blast of warm air from the Continent will send the mercury skyrocketing this weekend.WeatherOnline forecaster Garry Nicholson said: &ldquoHigh pressure will influence the British Isles heading into early September, bringing plenty of fair weather.&ldquoTemperatures rising, but there is uncertainty about how warm it will get - some indications draw in some very warm air from the continent by Sunday onward.&ldquoA little rain will come into the north-west at times.However the extended warm weather which kicked in during the start of spring could have a sting in the tail.While temperatures will remain high through to the end of the year, some forecasters say a severe late winter could be on the cards.Dr Todd Crawford, chief meteorologist with The Weather Company said: &ldquoWe&rsquove just experienced the warmest May-July period in many parts of northern and western Europe, including the UK.&ldquoWe expect this widespread warmth to continue into September, especially considering the relative dearth of the type of Atlantic tropical activity that could kick-start a more significant pattern change.&ldquoLooking ahead a bit into the autumn and winter, we expect warmer-than-normal temperatures to generally be the rule, especially across northern sections, in October and November.&ldquoThe very early evidence suggests that we could have some significant cold weather, however, especially in the back half of winter.

story: BBC Weather forecaster Carol Kirkwood told viewers that despite the wet start to the morning, &ldquoit&rsquos an improving picture if you like your weather drier and brighter with some sunshine.&ldquoAs we go through the rest of the week, for many of us it is going to become drier, but there will be cooler nights.Ms Kirkwood warned that some more rural parts of the country could see temperatures plummeting bringing with it a touch of frost.&ldquoWe&rsquove got a weather front which is sinking South, bringing with it cloud and some rain. we could see the odd flash of lightning this morning, but it&rsquos a low risk. (Image: BBC News Weather)Thursday could see pockets of frost across Southern England with temperatures dropping to as low as 5C early Thursday morning.&ldquoAcross the sheltered glens in Northern Scotland it could get as low as 3C, that&rsquos low enough for a touch of frost.&ldquoWe haven&rsquot seen that for a wee while.As we move later into Thursday morning, much of the UK will be seeing a lot of sunshine with some cloud moving in later in the day.&ldquoOur temperature range will be 14C in the North and up to 21C in the South.&ldquoAs we move into the weekend we&rsquoll see temperatures start to climb. We&rsquore looking at the high teens or indeed the low twenties by Saturday.&ldquoThen on Sunday, we&rsquoll see the low twenties to the mid-twenties further South.&ldquoSo Sunday doesn&rsquot look like a bad day you like it that wee bit warmer. It looks like the trend is that it&rsquoll get a bit warmer again as we head into the early part of next week.

title: Emmanuel Macron Nicolas Hulot France government French president news latest
story: Environment minister Nicolas Hulot resigned from the French Government during a bombshell live radio interview &ndash&nbspinsisting he felt &ldquoall alone in government.But former environment minister Brice Lalonde hit out at Mr Hulot and said the decision was a &ldquomistake.Speaking on France 24, Mr Lalonde said: &ldquoI think he is making a big mistake. I mean, it&rsquos a pity of course because he is a great guy he is very sincere. I think it&rsquos a mistake for three reasons.&ldquoOne, because the planet needs him. We need people like him to do things - to change course.                Macron pushes ahead huge cuts and EU reform despite falling support                Macron &lsquobleeding France dry&rsquo as economic growth forecast SLASHED&ldquoSecond, because in&nbspFrance&nbspand in Europe it is probably the place in the world&nbspin which the environment is protected the best. I mean, we have a real environmental policy and things are not going so bad.&ldquoThird, probably last but not least, nobody knew exactly what he wanted. The minister he had was a transition. But we don&rsquot know towards what.&ldquoWhat did he want? What is an ecological society? How do we live? How do we produce? Nobody knew about. Now, of course, we have this big frustration.&ldquoWhat did he want to do? Perhaps he is going to tell us now and perhaps we are going to understand.Emmanuel Macron's government in crisis as Nicolas Hulot resigns (Image: )When asked what might have motivated the decision to resign, Mr Lalonde said he believes it was because he was unable to transfer his &ldquobig vision into day-to-day politics.The former environment minister added: &ldquoWe always need people like him for the advocacy, to say what we want. That was probably lacking.&ldquoWhat is the direction? What is the horizon for which you want to bring us? This is lacking.&ldquoAnd I think we have a lot of environmentalists - they shout, they cry, they are never happy. But we don&rsquot have a real plan. How do we get where you want to bring us?Mr Hulot&rsquos departure will be a major blow to Mr Macron whose popularity among voters has hit record lows, according to opinion polls.He cited an accumulation of disappointments over green issues including the French government's failure to tackle climate change.Mr Hulot said: We're taking little steps, and France is doing a lot more than other countries, but are little steps enough? The answer is no.My decision comes from an accumulation of disappointments. I don't have faith in the state anymore.I don't want to give the illusion that my presence in the government means we are up to the task of meeting environmental challenges.Mr Hulot was known to be furious at the government's vow to relax hunting laws in a bid to a boost Mr Macron's appeal in rural areas.The left-winger also hit out at Mr Macron's decision to persist in a nuclear industry that is a useless madness, economically and technically.The French President faces further political turmoil as he embarks on a new wave of controversial reforms in the coming weeks.Mr Macron has promised to reform France's pensions system, overhaul public healthcare and change the highly unionised public sector.But his reform drive will be complicated by forecasts that France's economic growth is slower than expected.

title: Macron news EU migration news Macron Orban Salvini Milan meeting
story: Salvini and Orban have united against French President Emmanuel Macron  (Image: )The politicians met for talks on Tuesday in the Italian city of Milan where Mr Orban described Macron as &ldquothe leader of pro-migration parties in Europe today.&nbspMr Orban accused the French leader of welcoming illegal immigrants into his country and then Mr Salvini said the French leader was not helping Rome with migration issues when the country needed it as he turned back migrants at France&rsquos border with Italy.&nbspMr Orban said: &ldquoHe leads the European force that backs migration, he&rsquos the leader of those parties who back migration to Europe, and on the other side there&rsquos us who want to stop illegal migration.&ldquoOn this issue, there&rsquos a big debate also in the EPP (European People&rsquos Party).&nbsp                Juncker is the 'LAST European standing', claims his chief spokesman                Brigitte Macron changes into ethereal ballgown for state dinnerMr Salvini said the French leader did hardly anything to help Italy when it comes to migration and the country asks for help.&nbspHe has also repeatedly criticised the European Union over immigration and accused the bloc of abandoning Italy as it struggled to deal with the hundreds of thousands of migrants who have arrived since 2013.&nbspThe French president said that Rome had acted with &ldquocynicism and irresponsibility in turning away a migrant rescue ship.&nbspThe migrant rescue ship Aquarius was welcomed in Spain after it was turned away from other European countries.&nbspThe talks in Milan sparked protests against Orban and Salvini's policies  (Image: EPA )In response, Mr Salvini said the country had &ldquonothing to learn from anyone about generosity, voluntarism, welcoming and solidarity and demanded a formal apology from Mr Macron.&nbspMr Salvini demanded Mr Macron open the France-Italy border to ease pressures on his country.He added: &ldquoThe important thing for Italy is that it be a zero-sum exchange, which means we&rsquore willing to take back in our country the migrants involved in secondary movements as long as the same number of migrants are taken away from our country.France and Germany have been pushing for Italy to take back migrants who originally arrived in Italy but have since moved to other more northern European countries.Mr Orban&rsquos government has built a fence along Hungary&rsquos southern borders to keep out migrants and has congratulated Mr Salvini for stopping migration at sea.&nbspOrban and Salvini do not agree with Macron's migrant policies  (Image: )In June, Mr Salvini wrote on Twitter: &ldquoConfidence in Macron is crumbling.&ldquoThis is why he spends his time attacking the Italian government and its citizens.&nbspMr Salvini&rsquos meeting with Mr Orban comes after the Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte&rsquos summit with his Czech counterpart Andrej Babis, which also aimed at tackling migration issues.&nbsp

title: karren brady cbb dan osborne
story: The “theme” of this year’s CBB is that all the celebrities in the house have been embroiled in a scandal of some sort.But I would argue “scandal” is not quite the right word for the events that led to Osborne losing his role on Towie.In November 2014, Osborne was questioned over assault allegations after a fight with his ex, Megan Tomlin, although he was released without charge.A few months later, an audio recording emerged — allegedly secretly taken by Megan in November 2014 at her home — of Osborne apparently making foul-mouthed threats to “knife” Megan if she met another man, and referring to her as his “property”.That was three years ago, in 2015, and he went on to issue a public apology.He lost his job on Towie and also some lucrative endorsements which, no doubt, led to some soul-searching on his part.When talking about the “scandal” before entering the CBB house he said: “I said something that I never ever meant, I’m embarrassed by it. It was a horrible time.”In light of his apology, some people might talk about rehabilitation. He’s said he’s sorry and he won’t do it again.People have to be given a ­second chance — right?Before I answer that, let me flag up a few other stories that caught my eye this week.There’s the tale of Sean Simmons, 28, a domestic abuser from Hull who waterboarded one of his ex-partners, tying her to a bath before covering her face with a towel and pouring cold water over her, saying: “This is what I do to people who lie. I’m going to make you tell the truth.”Later, he produced a knife and said he’d “have to kill her”.And Darren McKie, a 43-year-old police inspector who was jailed for life after strangling his wife Leanne, 39, at their home in Cheshire, then dumping her body in a lake.And Glyn Leedell, 39, who threatened to kill a woman with a kitchen knife within hours of meeting her in a Rotherham pub.Oh, and the news that Ian Stewart, 57, who was jailed for 34 years after smothering his wife, children’s author Helen Bailey, is being questioned over the death of his first wife, Diane Stewart, who died after collapsing in the garden of the couple’s home in Cambridgeshire.I could go on, but it’s too depressing.If you read the same stories you may have taken a moment to despair that the papers are full of similar stories every day — of women being killed, brutalised and attacked by the men who purport to love them.Or, you may have barely noticed because these stories are so ­commonplace.Of course, not all men who threaten to kill their partners go on to do so.But you can be sure that most of the women above had probably suffered years of traumatic intimidation and abuse before their partners actually acted on their threats.Meanwhile, those women were ­living in fear — that’s what these chumps get off on. They want to make their victim feel helpless and powerless.So, let’s talk about forgiveness and rehabilitation.Do I think people who really regret being a perpetrator of domestic violence deserve a second chance? Yes, I do.If someone is genuinely ­repentant about anything they’ve done wrong, you can’t refuse ­forgiveness forever.Do I think that Dan Osborne’s second chance should take the form of a public platform on which to rehabilitate his image and, no doubt, earn a pretty penny or two into the bargain?No, I really, really do not.Sure, it was three years ago and no, he didn’t actually go on to act on his threat to knife his ex.But by letting him into the CBB house, Channel Five are sending a strong message that domestic violence allegations are a trivial affair, not to be taken seriously.By welcoming him in, despite his “scandal”, they are normalising and turning a blind eye to the kind of behaviour that too often ruins — and sometimes ends — women’s lives.People on TV are role models. And to allow a man who has made verbal threats to kill his girlfriend to become a role model is irresponsible in the extreme.ITV recognised this when they decided to boot him off Towie.Channel Five should have done the same.SHIRLEY BALLAS has revealed she weighs herself every day in the run up to Strictly in order to get “telly ready”.You might think that sounds extreme but, believe me, the only way to get telly ready is to take very seriously the old adage that the screen adds a stone.I don’t exactly weigh myself before filming The Apprentice or Give It A Year but, in the three months leading up to filming, I always manage to lose – by hook or by crook – a stone.In fact we all do – Lord Sugar and Claude Littner are watching what they eat as well.Then, as soon as filming stops, we all immediately put the weight back on again as normal life resumes.And, let me tell you, it’s a lot harder to take it off than it is to put it on.I’M a big believer in benefits being available to people who need help because they can’t help themselves.But the story of Bangladeshi immigrant Abdul Jalil, a father of six who came to the UK in 1969, really makes a mockery of the system.Jalil, who is 64, hasn’t worked since 1988 for “health reasons”.But a probation officer found the only problem he had is a slightly tender right knee.In 2008, he exceeded the amount of cash that claimants are allowed to have when he was loaned £25,000 to buy his council house.He did not notify the Department for Work and Pensions and continued wrongly claiming more than £28,000 over the next eight years.He then lied to the DWP about his assets as he filled out his benefits review form in 2012.He had re-mortgaged his council flat in May that year for roughly £148,000 and given the money to his children so they could purchase their own properties keeping around £86,500 for himself.Then at court this week he was spared jail – in favour of community service and even had the cheek to say he would do it if it was “light work”.I know that some people need benefits to get back on their feet, and I’m proud to live in a country that provides that.But once a person is back up, they need to actually stand on their own two feet – rather than abusing the system that helped them.Like all benefit cheats, he should pay the money back or go to jail and never be allowed access to benefits again.AS taxpayers we give almost £14BILLION a year away in foreign aid of which almost £1billion goes to the EU, and this week the Government was threatening to withdraw our cash if there was no-deal Brexit.Why wait until Brexit? Just stop it now.We need this money to fix our own country – our NHS, our police forces, our schools, benefits and housing all need it desperately.And the worst part of all this is that we have to borrow the money to give it away.Our country has almost £2TRILLION of debt, which costs around £50billion a year to service in interest.Borrowing money to give it away, it’s the economics of the madhouse.I KNOW our prisons are full, but it beggars belief that Allan Williamson, 45, was let off with a two-year community order and 30 days rehabilitation.When police raided his flat in Hulme, Manchester, they found more than 600 images – including 68 films classed as Category A, the highest level of children being sexually abused.To be clear, the images showed children as young as seven being sexually abused by adults.Still, Judge Elizabeth Nicholls,  decided prison wasn’t necessary, saying Williamson had been “open and frank” with the police about his behaviour and because the man has allegedly taken “tentative steps to address these issues”.So the guy was in possession of 600 images including many of the worst kind of paedophilia – and he’s still in the community?Who in their right mind would want this guy in their community?I know the prisons are buckling, so let’s just build more – even if that includes sending prisoners out to sea in containers.When is the justice system going to start thinking about the victims as opposed to the perpetrators?I BET the boyfriend of Kay Longstaff – the air hostess who spent ten hours in the water after plunging from a cruise liner – is feeling a bit embarrassed.Longstaff was miraculously rescued ten hours after falling – or jumping – from the Norwegian Star, 60 miles off the Croatian coast last week.It’s not quite clear what happened beforehand but other passengers and crew claim to have seen Ms Longstaff in several arguments with her partner Craig Rayment, above with Kay, on the evening of the incident.Once she’d been rescued, Mr Rayment’s estranged wife Kelly offered Ms Longstaff some unsolicited support, saying: “If I was on a ship with him, I would get off any way I could.”Oh dear.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: politicians dont answer questions
story: I have made my peace with this and accepted, regardless of the fact I have never fiddled my expenses or taken cash for ­questions, some of those who come before me have damned all politicians to the sin-bin.I do, however, think there is one very simple thing all politicians could agree to do that would help rehabilitate us to the public.We could answer a straight question with a straight answer.This week doing the rounds on Twitter was a clip of Jeremy Corbyn on Channel 4 News being asked six times: “Do you honestly believe Britain will be better off outside of the EU?”Each time he answered with a iation of, “Labour wants to maintain good relations with the EU to protect jobs”.His words are not bad — it is certainly the answer he and his team would have practised.But it is not an answer to that question and that’s the problem.To the average punter it just looks like politicians can’t be straight.The answer, as far as I’m concerned, is a big fat no.Gavin Williamson, the Defence Secretary, suffered a similar cringeworthy encounter with Richard Madeley in May.The question in the wake of the Salisbury poisonings was: “You told Russia to ‘shut up and go away’.Do you regret that now?Do you think it was too informal?”He started by answering an entirely different question about paying tribute to healthcare workers, which had absolutely nothing to do with what he was being asked.God only knows why he didn’t just say: “Yeah, it wasn’t my finest hour but I guess I was just really cross that people in Britain were being poisoned.”He could then have gone on to say all the nice things about Salisbury health workers.Instead, Madeley savaged him and all that anyone remembers of the encounter is that Gavin Williamson should avoid interviews.Mind you, at least both Corbyn and Williamson gave an answer.At least they bothered to take part.Boris Johnson would just have offered his questioner a cup of tea as if he was Mrs Doyle from Father Ted.I honestly despair.I’m not sure when the art of just repeating the same message over and over again, even if it in no way answers the question, started.Most people put it down to the Tony Blair years of slick media management, but times have surely got to move on.Politicians spend too much time hedging their bets, trying to keep all the people happy and end up pleasing no one by waffling through an answer that is basically six of one and half a dozen of the other.I get that it is hard when your job is basically a massive popularity contest, but I am not sure we are made more popular by dodging questions and refusing to give our own opinions.People contact me every single week telling me they don’t always agree with me but they appreciate that I stand up for what I believe.I honestly don’t think the British people want politicians to say an approximation of a safe answer, or to try to be pals with everyone.People have a damn sight more respect for people when they say what they think, even if they disagree.For too long politicians have been especially scared of upsetting working-class people, without recognising that most people don’t even think of themselves that way any more.I have absolutely no idea where the idea came from that the average member of the public can’t stand a bit of discussion and disagreement, or are so fragile that they will all fall apart if someone says something not to their liking.I have never once voted for someone who I agreed with 100 per cent of the time.I didn’t marry someone I agreed with a 100 per cent of the time and, frankly, if he tried to please me, placate me and pander to all my views I would no longer stay married to him, because it would be dishonest.Don’t get me wrong — saying what you think is not a universally appreciated characteristic and some do get in touch with me to tell me to shut up and go away.Much like Russia probably felt when Williamson said it to them, I pay little mind to this and crack on.Journalists do sometimes ask stupid questions.Politicians do have to be careful about what they say as it can sometimes get twisted and misrepresented.Things are not always simple, and giving a quick answer on a complex issue takes some skill.All that said, it has got to be time to stop the waffle and give the public a break from shouting at their telly each night: “For God’s sake, answer the bleedin’ question!”IT’S that time of year where slow news weeks turn to how much wine we should drink and if swearing at work should be banned.Apparently no amount of alcohol is safe, which will change absolutely no one’s behaviour, and swearing at work is bad for morale.I cannot agree on the swearing front.I am not advocating we all run around barking sweary orders and aggressive expletives at our colleagues but I find sometimes, especially in times of high stress in the office, nothing will quite explain it like a collective FFS.I have seen how a bit of good old Anglo Saxon can be used to break down barriers between me and my constituents.It stops me seeming like some lofty bureaucrat who cannot understand their problems.In some cases it makes them physically relax if we get a bit sweary about their crappy landlord or their benefits being stopped.We all swear, and most of us drink, I doubt that’s going to change.PADDY DOHERTY of My Big Fat Gypsy Wedding and Celeb Big Brother fame was in the papers this week, leading the funeral procession for his nephew.A sad affair, of course, but the diamond-encrusted funeral casket is reported to have cost £100,000.I remember organising my own mother’s funeral and balking at spending around £2,500 for an event I’d rather have not had to attend.I could hear her voice in my head saying, “How much?” as we wrote out cheques for cars and coffins. My wedding only cost £3k and I thought that was a bit much.When my time comes, I implore my family to keep their cash. I wouldn’t be thankful for money being literally burnt.THIS week’s, in fact this year’s, feminist icon goes to the unlikely Stormy Daniels.There is, of course, no reason why feminism would not extend to women performing in pornography but there are few crossovers.Stormy Daniels is a hero.World leaders across the globe pander to Trump, few are brave enough to publicly call out his racism, sexism and terrible decision making.Our own PM holds his hand, allowing him to make her look weak and feeble.Ms Daniels has been brave enough not only to take on the most powerful man in the world but also some pretty tooled-up lawyers too.After apparently receiving payment and signing a non-disclosure agreement to hush her up about an affair she had with Trump in 2006, she broke rank.This was not just a kiss and tell, this was a story that has caused Donald Trump’s lawyer Michael Cohen to plead guilty to breaking election campaign rules.He explicitly stated that he was told to pay her the money by “the candidate” meaning Trump. Donald Trump will probably get away with this misdemeanour, but it is the closest he has come to being in real trouble.Without Stormy Daniels and her courage to face down legal threats, vicious hate mail and a campaign to discredit her, powerful men would continue to use women as playthings and just pay them off when they are done.Stormy Daniels is every woman who has been messed about and we salute her for fighting back.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: just ignore bogus chancellor hammond the sun is brexing out
story: Of course, she was right to ask.Not a single public authority predicted the biggest crash in modern history — not the Bank of England, not the ­Treasury, and certainly not the Chancellor of the Exchequer.Then in 2016 they did it again. Project Fear forecast dramatic downturns in the economy if the people were so unwise as to vote for Brexit. Wrong again.Since then, we have had record levels of employment, huge investments from the likes of Google, Microsoft, SoftBank and a long list of other companies.They demonstrated their confidence in the future of this great country in the best way possible — with their money.This time round the wise insight came from Andy Haldane, the best economist at the Bank of England.Ruefully he said “economic forecasting is having a Michael Fish moment”.Michael Fish was the weather forecaster who completely mispredicted the huge 1987 storm that struck Britain.If only economic forecasters were even as good as weather forecasters, we would be a lot better off. But they are not, and they are at it again.This week Chancellor Philip Hammond predicted the Treasury would need to raise an extra £80billion in 15 years’ time in the event of a no-deal Brexit.And yet the Chancellor insists on ­trotting out yet another bogus forecast, on the very day that my successor as Brexit Secretary, Dominic Raab, is ­presenting the first set of preparation for no deal.Coincidence? I do not think so.The great departments of state are very careful about what they put in the public domain, and exactly when.For nobody is this more true than the Treasury, which has to judge the public perception of everything it does, if only because of its effect on the markets. So this was either spectacularly incompetent, or deliberate. I know what I think.And even more disgraceful, by doing so it will undermine the Government’s hand in striking a deal with the EU.If they do not think we dare walk away, then they will give us the worst deal they can think of. Bear in mind that the Chequers deal already concedes enormous amounts to the EU.It would not be long before our world-leading position in life sciences, gene technology, artificial intelligence, self-driving cars and a whole range of other modern industries would be being actively undermined by the Europeans.As for being out of reach of the ­European Court, pull the other one.But now the Treasury is beginning to fear that even these spectacular concessions the Government has made in the Chequers deal will not deliver agreement from the European Commission — or if it does, the Commons will turn it down.In that event you can expect attempts by the Remainers in Parliament to try to scupper our departure by delaying it beyond the General Election, or offer some other enormous raft of concessions to give back control of the EU.Hence the ridiculous suggestion that the Army would be used to move food around the country.Why? What conceivable aspect of European policy would handicap British hauliers moving British products from Kent to Cumbria?None of course, but it was just the bogus nonsense some of our Remainer media is only too happy to carry ­completely uncritically. Similarly, we have heard suggestions of all sorts of shortages, based it seems mostly on the idea that the French might impede the flow of goods between Calais and Dover.It would not be the first time we had dealt with such issues. We had about 30 days of such delays in 2015. I remember queues of lorries, but I do not remember shortages of food or medicines.And on other issues, are the Europeans really going to pick a fight on data with the biggest IT power on the continent, on banking are they going to refuse to cooperate with the greatest financial ­centre in the world?Are the Greeks, Italians and Spaniards going to disadvantage the UK residents on whom many of their local economies depend? Or stop tourism? I think not.I suspect we are quite likely to have the odd hiccup when we leave the EU, but we will be able to cope, which is what Dominic Raab was demonstrating this week. And any problems we have will be over in months not years.So in 15 years’ time, far from worrying about Mr Hammond’s £80billion bill, the country will have trouble remembering what all the fuss was about.The biggest question will be whether we have made the most of the opportunities created by Brexit.And that is what we should worry about today, creating the circumstances where this great country can take its proper place in the world. We will only be able to do that if we allow ourselves the freedoms a clean Brexit will deliver.So my advice to all my old colleagues in Cabinet is simple: Ignore the misery merchants of the Treasury, stop fearing things that will never happen, and start planning for the real opportunities that this great country can grasp when it sets its mind to it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun says theresa may trade deals africa
story: A major factor of the Leave vote was for Britain to become an independent nation, free to strike global trade deals with fast-growing, emerging economies.So the Prime Minister is absolutely right to start outlining trade policy with our Commonwealth allies South Africa, Nigeria and Kenya.She is also right to call for funds from our bloated foreign aid budget to be diverted from frivolous handouts and used instead on developing infrastructure and security in Africa.As we unshackle ourselves from Brussels, it is clear Africa presents us with huge opportunities.It is the world’s second biggest continent, home to 16 per cent of the global population. Its GDP is growing rapidly. Similar to India, its middle classes are rocketing. And its workforce is estimated to be larger than China’s by 2035.Over 17 millions Brits voted for a Brexit that would make us a freer, richer country.This is exactly the type of buccaneering move that will make that vision a reality.THE EU’s threats regarding a No Deal Brexit are total bluster.The bloc claims there will be chaos if we leave without a deal, that the impact on trade and travel will be so severe we will crawl back to the negotiating table.But behind closed doors, the EU admits this is codswallop.The EU Commission has drawn up secret No Deal plans that are “very similar” to Britain’s Brexit preparation.In other words, in the event of a No Deal they will keep things almost exactly the same because they don’t want to be hit.What a surprise.WHEN will Labour moderates realise their party is beyond repair?Jewish Labour MPs need bodyguards for the party conference next month. There is a backlog of anti-Semitism complaints that could take YEARS to probe. And their leader is an ­anti-Semitic IRA-apologist, who counts the former BNP leader and the KKK among his cheerleaders.By staying in the party, Labour MPs signal that they want Corbyn to be PM.No amount of tribal loyalty can make them think that is a good idea.IT is shocking that deadly diet pills are being brazenly flogged on Instagram.The Facebook-owned company must better protect youngsters.It should hire a proper workforce to establish oversight of what is put online.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gps behind closed doors
story: From draining pus-filled cysts and manually evacuating bowels - where patients stools are extracted by hand from the rectum - to dealing with smelly feet and performing vasectomies: what really goes down at the doctors is much more gruesome than you may think.Now, a Channel 5 documentary series lays bare the reality of being a GP, revealing what really goes on in the consultation room.In June, a family doctor in Russia pulled a parasitic worm from the eyebrow of a 32-year-old woman, who had been puzzled by a mysterious itchy bump shed nursed for two weeks.While earlier this year Florida woman Katie Holley, 29,woke up with a flying cockroach stuck in her ear, which had to be removed by doctors in several pieces in a gruesome ordeal.Doctors have even had to deal with people vomiting poo, with one Reddit user saying: we had an elderly man with a bowel obstruction basically vomiting stool. I dont enjoy the smell of vomit or stool, but the two mixed together was one of the worst things Ive ever smelled.One doctor on chat site Quora said one of the worst things he had witnessed was a patient battling a flesh-eating disease in his arm and leg that had maggots crawling around in it.And of course, theres US-based doctor Sandra Lee - aka Doctor Pimple Popper who has become a breakout star, with her videos of lancing giant boils  - some as big as bowling balls - as well as spots and cysts gaining a staggering five million views on YouTube.Earlier this year, Dr Lee even removed a unicorn horn worth of pus from a lump that had been growing on a mans head for six years.It took 20 minutes for the doctor to remove all of the pus - which poured out in a manner resembling cottage cheese - before stitching the resulting wound back together.“People sometimes think the real doctors work in hospitals and GPs only treat coughs and colds,” Dr Amir Khan, star of Channel 5’s GPs: Behind Closed Doors, tells Sun Online.“But that’s far from the truth.We deal with all sorts of problems every day and some of them would make your eyes water.Dr Khan said: “We deal with all sorts of problems every day and some of them would make your eyes water.“It’s the same for every GP, it’s just a part of the job.“There’s no way you could be a GP and let being squeamish affect what you do.“You sort of just get used to it.“For example, I really dislike feet when I’m at home and you see it on telly, but at work it’s just another thing to deal with.”“Once you’ve manually evacuated someone’s bowels, there’s nothing left to phase you.But despite performing essential medical procedures in the surgery, Khan admits hes concerned that these services may not be available in the future.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may brexit better off second referendum
story: The Prime Minister was asked SIX times if she thinks the UK can thrive even with No Deal - and if she would vote for Brexit in a second referendum.But she declined to answer the question - insisting that she is focussed on cutting a trade deal with Europe.Mrs Mays ministers last week laid out No Deal plans which are designed to help the UK cope with the potential collapse of talks with Brussels.But when asked if the proposals would be enough to ensure that Britain is better off after Brexit no matter what the outcome, the PM wouldnt reply.During a visit to South Africa, she said to Sky News: What were working for with the European Union is a good deal.Of course its right because we dont know the outcome of the negotiations that we prepare for No Deal.Asked a second time, Mrs May insisted there were huge opportunities open to the United Kingdom after Brexit, adding: What the Government is working for is to ensure that whatever the outcome of the negotiations, we make a success of leaving the European Union.After she ignored the question twice more, the PM was asked whether shed vote Leave if there was a re-run of the referendum.She again dodged the issue, saying: That is a hypothetical question, and I dont answer hypothetical questions because were not in the business of having - and its very important this point - because were not in the business of having a second referendum on Brexit.What were in the business of doing is delivering Brexit, so actually what someone would vote for today is not the issue.Pressed a second time, Mrs May again refused to answer.The PMs dodge comes a week after Jeremy Corbyn similarly refused to say whether he believed the UK will be better off after Brexit.Both leaders campaigned for Remain in the referendum but have committed to respecting the result of the vote in 2016.Critics mocked Mrs May for avoiding the crucial question - Lib Dem MP Tom Brake, who backs the Peoples Vote campaign, said: “We are in the unprecedented and unenviable situation of having a Prime Minister who clearly does not believe that her own Government’s flagship policy – Brexit – is in the best interests of the country.And yet she insists on inflicting it on us all anyway.

title: david cameron michael gove memoir jibe
story: Sources close to the former PM say he has finally finished writing his long-awaited account of his time in power.And our revelation lays bare the animosity he is set to reveal for Mr Gove, who he blames for ending his political career by defeating him in the EU referendum.At a party with fellow Tories earlier this summer, Mr Cameron joked: “As you know I’ve been working on my book.“It’s taken a while and quite a bit longer than expected.“To give you an idea of my progress, I’m on chapter 37 and Michael Gove is still one of the good guys.”The latest sign of Mr Cameron’s grudge towards Mr Gove comes after The Sun revealed earlier this year that he plays an online game that lets players bash his foe.“Whack a Gove” users bop a mole-like cartoon of the politician for points.The Tory duo fell out spectacularly over the EU.Mr Cameron has vowed never to forgive him for taking charge of the successful Vote Leave campaign in 2016. The pair and their wives had been close chums but have not spoken since Mr Cameron quit as PM hours after Britain backed Brexit.The former PM was initially planning to publish his explosive memoirs this autumn but opted to delay until next year to avoid his comments undermining Theresa May’s crunch Brexit negotiations.He has promised to give a “frank” in his account of his six years in No10 - raising fears among the Tory leadership that they will spark fresh Cabinet rifts.In another sign of the hatred he will reveal for Mr Gove, he told friends earlier this summer that the current Environment Secretary behaved like a “lunatic” in the referendum campaign.Allies say Mr Cameron had no idea Mr Gove would betray him by choosing to back Brexit and didn’t realise “quite how mad he was,” according to the Sunday Times.And revealing that he blames Mr Gove much more than Boris Johnson for ending his time in power, Mr Cameron’s friends added: “He was saying he feels even more cross with Gove than Boris.”He hasn’t spoken to Mr Gove since he left No10 in July 2016. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may strictly invite after dance moves
story: The PM, 61, swayed awkwardly from side to side and bobbed up and down as she was greeted by a group of dancing pupils.Mrs May, who was in Cape Town to announce a scholarship programme for 100 African youngsters to study in Britain, smiled and laughed throughout.And she went on to join in with a second dance at the South African city’s I D Mkize School.The PM, dubbed the Maybot by critics, joked: “I think the chances of Strictly Come Dan­cing coming calling are pretty minimal.”And after social media users branded her “Twinkle Toes Theresa”, she quipped: “I’ve been called many things in my time.”Later Mrs May visited Robben Island, where late President Nelson Mandela was held for 18 years during the apartheid era.The PM also announced yesterday that Britain would “roll over” the EU’s existing free trade deal with South Africa in the wake of Brexit.IT’S been proven that politicians have no natural rhythm. You only have to look at Ed Balls and Ann Widdecombe to see that.Now we can add Theresa May to the list. Frankly, it was embarrassing to watch — like bad mum dancing.But at least she gave it a go. You have to praise Theresa for trying. It would have been disrespectful if she hadn’t done it.I’ll give her two out of ten for effort — one point for each leg.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kids soft play boss caught filming schoolgirls peepholes public swimming pool
story: Former Eddie Catz boss Darren Johnson, 51, used peepholes to film women in toilets and changing rooms at a centre where parents take their young children to have fun.The married dad-of-two also followed youngsters when they attended a leisure centre for swimming lessons before using a mobile phone to look under their cubicles as they changed, Kingston Crown Court heard.Johnson, from Putney in south-west London, was finally caught when two 14-year-old girls spotted his iPhone 6 from under the adjacent cubicle and alerted staff.He was identified from CCTV footage and police seized two computers containing hundreds of images of women in ious states of undress.Johnson admitted five counts of voyeurism over a period of 12 years, between January 1 2005 and June 5 2017, although his barrister Tom Williams said his offending occurred over a few months in 2007 and a second period in 2016 and 2017.But he backed down on claims Johnson had not meant to film teenagers after prosecutors refused to agree.Prosecutor Lauren Sales said: There is CCTV which shows the defendant stalking children around the leisure centre. He attended the leisure centre at times when schools have swim classes.He goes up to the swimming pool, sees the kids, sees them using the facilities, stalks them to the shower area and stalks them to the cubicle area and uses the cubicle next to them.There was a 12-year-old he was following as well. It is all shown very clearly on the CCTV.The court heard no charges were brought in relation to the 12-year-old.Ms Sales said: At the time of the offences, he was the director of Eddie Catz, which are soft play centres for young children.The number of victims is not known, although a police officer involved in the case estimated it could be around 40.Judge Andrew Campbell said: We are certainly running into the tens, twenties and possibly very many more.The company has centres in Earlsfield, Putney, Wimbledon and Newbury, as well as a presence in branches of Mothercare in Leeds, Gateshead, Manchester, Solihull and Cribbs Causeway, near Bristol.Johnsons lawyer said his client had enjoyed a successful sporting career, which took him to Italy, but was plagued by alcohol problems and marriage troubles after he was injured.Two of the voyeurism charges relate to the filming of the 14-year-old girls, while a third relates to images of women taken under cubicles at the leisure centre.Two further charges relate to images of women taken through peepholes and under cubicles in toilets and changing rooms at the soft play centre.

title: stefan mandel romania lottery money system
story: After years of painstaking research, he devised a “number-picking algorithm” which drew on a method he called “combinatorial condensation” - stay with us.Stefan realised that in some draws, the total cost of buying a ticket to play every possible combination was much lower than the grand jackpot prize.For example, if a game required six numbers ranging between 1 and 40 to be chosen, there would be 3,838,380 possible number combinations.If the jackpot was £10 million, and tickets cost £1 each, he stood to win a massive profit.Along with a group of friends, he bought huge amounts of tickets using all the possible combinations and ended up taking out the top prize — worth over £15,000 .After paying expenses, he was left with just £3,000, but it was enough to bribe officials and escape Romania’s Communist system, and move to Australia to start a new life with his wife and two kids.He eventually won the lottery 14 times without breaking a single law.Stefan persuaded a pool of investors to put their cash together to build a lotto syndicate.He also invented an automation system, with printers and computers using the algorithm to fill out tickets automatically using every combination of numbers.The group won 12 lotteries and won hundreds of thousands of smaller prizes across Australia and the UK.Lotto authorities cottoned onto the plot, and changed rules to ban computer-printed forms and bulk buying tickets.But Stefan had an audacious plan B.With the profits he’d already made, he planted scouts across the US and also developed a list of previous lotteries with jackpots that were at least three times higher than the total of all possible combinations.He set his sights on the Virginia Lottery, as its numbers only ranged between one and 44, which meant the total number of possible combinations was millions lower than in other games.He set up an official company, Pacific Financial Resources, and under it also developed a trust called the International Lotto Fund.He persuaded thousands of investors to pour cash into the fund, raising millions in the process.From a warehouse in Melbourne he employed 16 full-time staff to print out seven million tickets over three months, which he then mailed to an associate in the US.The syndicate won the jackpot and a host of smaller prizes.But while Mr Mandel’s method was not illegal, it still raised suspicions, and he was dragged into a four-year legal battle.He was eventually cleared of any wrongdoing — but while he managed to pocket millions from the win, his investors were left with much smaller payouts that promised.Mr Mandel filed for bankruptcy in 1995 and at one point spent 20 months behind bars in Israel thanks to an investment scam.All US states have since passed laws banning the use of Mr Mandel’s strategy.But despite his epic gamble, Mr Mandel downplayed the risks he had faced during a 2012 interview with the Romanian newspaper, Bursa.“I’m a man who takes risks, but in a calculated way,” he told the publication.“Trimming my beard is a lottery: There is always the possibility that I’ll cut myself, get an infection in my blood and die — but I do it anyway.“The chances are in my favour.A version of this story originally appeared on news.au.

title: step dad broke nine of babys bones
story: Johnathan Neiger-Bickham faces charges of second-degree child abuse after the newborn was found with four broken ribs, a broken right femur, right tibia, and arm busted in three places.He was arrested for child abuse after cops were called during a heated row with the tots mum.Neiger-Bickham threatened the woman, his girlfriend, with a knife as he travelled to buy heroin near their home in Muskegon Heights, Michigan.The woman fled the row and was in the care of Child Protective Services, who advised her to have the baby medically examined.Neiger-Bickman told investigators the baby was injured accidentally when he picked him up quickly when he started choking.He said he heard a sudden clicking form the right side of the tot.The thugs also told cops on another occasion he rolled over while sleeping and accidentally hit the baby, giving him a black eye.Child Protective Services has removed the baby from the home.Neiger-Bickman is being held on £80,000 bond ahead of a September 5 court appearance.He faces further charges of breaking into a vacant house and stealing an AR-15 assault rifle, breaking into a barn to steal a quad bike, and possession of a firearm.He was convicted in 2007 of killing three teenagers in a drink driving smash.

title: super recognisers catch novichok assassins
story: The two Scotland Yard detectives have trawled 5,000 hours of CCTV footage trying match faces in Salisbury at the time of the poisoning with images of Heathrow passengers.The two super recognisers are specialists in memorising and recognising faces and believed to be behind the identification of two suspects who the UK authorities now want to extradite from Russia.They were dispatched to Salisbury shortly after Sergei Skripal, 67, and daughter Yulia, 33, were poisoned with nerve agent Novichok, in March.It is believed they were shown images of known Russian agents suspected of operating in the UK before searching for their faces on Salisburys CCTV.Former detective chief inspector Mick Neville, who set up the squad, said: The two super recognisers were deployed immediately because of their special skills and they are still on the case. Ive no doubt theyve played a key role.They have an innate skill, you cant buy it and you cant teach it. They have a highly unusual ability in remembering faces, whether its from a picture, a bit of film or someone theyve met.They dont concentrate on the obvious, the greying hair or the moustache or the glasses, they look at the eyes, the mouth, the ears, the things that dont change. They can recognise a face from the tiniest glimpse of part of it.The intelligence agencies will have images of foreign agents who come here and once they are scanned by the super recognisers they will be imprinted in their memory.The squad was set up in the wake of the 2011 London riots and helped identify the killer of schoolgirl Alice Gross in West London in 2014.Police believe the Skripals, who both recovered from the attempted assassination, were poisoned by Novichok smeared on the front door handle of their Salisbury home.Mr Neville added: Sergei was living openly with his real name registered in the voters database and seemingly unconcerned at the possibility of being assassinated.But he may have had security because he was worried about being burgled and so might his neighbours, so its possible the would-be killers were caught on a camera in the act.Vehicles moving around with dashboard cameras might also have recorded an image.Its possible the attackers followed the Skripals into the city centre the next day to make sure that the poison finally worked and there are lots of cameras around the bench where the victims were found.Its a laborious part of the operation, but there is plenty of material for the super recognisers to work on.The Kremlin denies being involved in any Novichok poisoning plot.Dawn Sturgess, 45, died in June, just 10 days after coming into contact with Novichok believed to be stored inside a perfume bottle. Her partner Charlie Rowley, 45, survived but has since been rushed back to hospital with suspected meningitis.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: manchester blue light pulsating ufo
story: Locals spotted the ominous glow in the sky above Stalybridge, Greater Manchester, at around 11pm on Monday evening.Social media sites were soon flooded with shots of the mysterious glow - with one user claiming it came from a giant spaceship.Others speculated that it was part of the Pride Festival celebrations in Manchester city centre.One wrote: It was really odd. It was there for a fair few seconds then moved to the left.Another added: Anyone see the strange purple lights over Tameside earlier? UFO invasion?But the phenomenon turned out to be a laser-guided train making repairs to a nearby set of tracks.A Network Rail spokeswoman said confirmed that a tamping train was carrying out maintenance in the area that night.She said: “We can confirm this was not an unidentified flying object . It was rather an identified non-flying object  - namely a railway ballast tamping machine, which uses lasers.”

title: new caledonia earthquake magnitude 7 south pacific
story: The South Pacific island was rocked by the tremors at a shallow depth of six miles.Its epicentre was 230 miles east of the New Caledonia capital, Noumea.The US Pacific Tsunami Center said there is little chance of the quake causing tsunamis.We felt it and they felt it more strongly on the Loyalty Islands, Civil Defense spokesman Olivier Ciry told Reuters by phone from Noumea.But there is nothing to say. There is no damage, no tsunami and we dont expect anything else, he said.Also known as megathrust earthquakes, they occur at subduction zones - where one tectonic plate moves under another and sinks due to gravity into the mantle.They are the planets most powerful quakes, with magnitudes that can exceed 9.0.The major subduction zone is associated with the Pacific and Indian Oceans - an area responsible for volcanic activity associated with the Ring of Fire.These kind of earthquakes deform the ocean floor, which often causes tsunami waves.Intense shaking can last for up to a few minutes.In Japan, the Nankai megathrust beneath the Nankai trough is responsible for Nankai megathrust earthquakes and tsunamis.The Earth has been rocked by a spate of tremors in recent weeks.The latest quake in Venezuela was so powerful the effects were felt in the Caribbean islands of Trinidad and Tobago and Grenada.There are fears a megaquake could strike are mounting after 214 earthquakes have hit the planet in the past week.Around 70 quakes are thought to have hit the Ring of Fire - a horseshoe-shaped area of volcanic belts, arcs and tectonic plates.The area stretches 25,000 miles from South America to Australia via the western United States and East Asia.

title: benefit freeze sees brits have to choose between heating eating and rent as prices soar
story: Even the cheapest homes are now out of reach for Brits claiming housing benefit, ministers have been warned.A freeze is set to remain in place until at least 2020 - and it now means many tenants have to make up a shortfall of up to £3,000 a year as their rents rise.Research from the Chartered Institute for Housing  showed that more than 90 per cent of housing benefits rates across Britain dont cover the cheapest rents anymore.They demanded ministers urgently end the benefits freeze or it will make even more homeless.And its hitting the under 25s even harder because they are only entitled to benefits to cover one bedroom in a shared home.And the problem was worst in commuter towns like Cambridge, Milton Keynes and Chelmsford, where the weekly shortfalls on a four-bed home were up to £68.It means a real-terms cut to most working families as the cost of living rises.But the moves saves around £1.9billion worth of cash for the Treasury.CIH chief executive Terrie Alafat CBE said: “Our research makes it clear just how far housing benefit for private renters has failed to keep pace with even the cheapest private rents. We fear this policy is putting thousands of private renters on low incomes at risk of poverty and homelessness.“We are calling on the government to conduct an immediate review and to look at ending the freeze on Local Housing Allowance.”And Matt Downie, Director of Policy at housing charity crisis added: This report highlights just how much housing benefits for private renters are falling short of the levels needed, leaving many homeless people stuck in a desperate situation and putting yet more people at risk of homelessness.Your energy bills are a priority debt - that means you should pay them off before other bills like your credit card as your supplier could threaten to cut your supply-off completely.But dont bury your head in the sand. Contact your energy firm as soon as you can and discuss your situation.It has to help you reach a solution, likely through a payment plan.This is where you pay a fixed-amount which you can afford over a set period of time.The plan will cover the debt you owe and the energy you are using now.If you cant reach an agreement, your supplier might insist on installing a pre-payment meter but this is only as a last resort.A government spokesperson said: “We spend £24bn a year on housing benefit each year. And since April we’ve provided additional, targeted housing support for low-income households by increasing more than 200 local housing allowance rates.“Since 2011, we have provided a further £1bn in discretionary housing payment for local authorities to support vulnerable claimants with their housing costs.“We have also delivered over 378,000 new affordable properties since 2010 and we are investing a further £9bn in affordable homes to buy and rent.”

title: luxury six bed home on market for 1m is hiding two amazing secrets
story: But theres more to The Limes than meets the eye.The luxury home has its own BUNKER hidden in its grounds.The extremely rare concrete WW2 air raid shelter is still intact and accessible to the homeowners and previous occupants have used it as storage space.And thats not all - a sealed up secret school room is hidden away under the floorboards of the house.A piece of angled skirting board and an area of the flooring that feels ‘bouncy’ mark where the concealed entrance to the school room is.Deep in the garden, a concrete air raid shelter from the Second World War is hidden away under a rockeryThe Limes also has other quirky historic features including servants quarters, a wood burning fireplace and a cellar.Natalie Carter at Fine &amp Country said: “The Limes is a wonderful example of how history makes its mark on houses through the generations.“The servants’ quarters are typical of Georgian houses, while the bunker is a rare existing example of a concrete air raid shelter.“And now, having studied the history and walked the house, it appears theres a former school room under the house thats been sealed up.The house is currently on the market for £1million.All of the six bedrooms are doubles and the garden has several fruit trees and vegetable patches.The large sitting and drawing rooms on the ground floor offer large living space, with each room having a bay window and French windows overlooking the garden, allowing in plenty of light and direct access to the lawn.And the kitchen features an Aga range in addition to an electric oven and gas hob, with a separate pantry and boot room.Tucked away is an office overlooking the garden and just off the kitchen is a good size dining room linking the kitchen with the hallway.The first floor leads to four of the six double bedrooms, one of which has an en-suite bathroom, and the additional two bedrooms can be found on the top floor.People interested in buying the house will undoubtedly be drawn by both its history and impressive space.And theres still room to put your own stamp on the The Limes when its snapped up. While the original house is listed, the extension housing the kitchen, laundry room and study is unlisted, offering potential to convert this area of the house into a significant kitchen, dining and garden room subject to planning permission.Foodies can enjoy produce from several fruit trees bearing mulberries, apples and pears while the vegetable garden offers a good selection of vegetables, fruits and herbs.At the bottom of the garden there are three sheds and a gate leading into the church grounds, and one down to the river Thames.

title: eagle eyed google users spot something terrifying lurking in a cemetery on street view
story: The video is taken from Google Maps Street View of Martha Chapel Cemetery in Texas, USA and features a creepy looking little girl hiding behind a tree with a cloaked figure in the background.Video of the Street View shows a sunny scene but as the camera pans gravestones can be seen among the pine trees.The camera stops panning and settles on a tree behind which lurks a strange figure.After zooming in, a little girl is seen peeking around the left side of the tree. She is grey-faced.The girl may or may not be a child simply playing in the woods, but her identity remains unknown.However, there appears to be a second figure lurking in the field behind the cemetery, a cloaked and slender figure.The video has been viewed more than 10,000 times and viewers believe they saw a supernatural being.One viewer commented: The first looks like definitive proof of something.Another added: Perhaps of a murder or simply could have died on an accident.Either way its poor soul is out roaming this Earth.A third commentator said: Creepy - gives me the chills!There have been a spate or reported wraith encounters recently.Ghost hunters in Maltby, South Yorkshire, have reported seeing a 6ft monk holding a crucifix.A spectral pedestrian was seen crossing a road through traffic in the Philippines.

title: quarter 14yo girls self harm
story: The Children’s Society warns 110,000 kids of that age deliberately hurt themselves as they struggled to cope with life’s pressures.They say concerns about looks, sexuality, gender stereotypes and school performance are the main reasons for unhappiness.The charity said more needs to be done to improve children’s mental health, including greater access to counsellors in schools.One young person said: I felt like self-harming was what I wanted to do and had to do as there was nothing else I could do.“I think there is help for young people but not the right kind of help.Feeling not pretty enough or good enough as other girls did contribute towards my self-harming.”The poll of 11,144 kids born in 2000/1 reveals 16% self-harmed in 2015, when they were 14.The figure rose to 22% among the girls and fell to 9% among the boys.Matthew Reed, from the Children’s Society, said: It is deeply worrying that so many children are unhappy to the extent that they are self-harming.”He said all secondary schools should offer access to a counsellor and wants mental health care to be assessed as part of Ofsted inspections.Mr Reed added: “Issues like appearance, gender stereotypes and sexuality should be included in the new Relationships and Sex Education curriculum.Early support for vulnerable children and families in the community, which can help prevent mental health problems from developing, is also vital.”Roy Perry, from the Local Government Association, said the figures revealed a “crisis in childrens mental health”.He added: “This is why we are calling for councils and schools to be given the funding to offer independent mental health counselling so pupils have access to support as and when they need it.We need to develop a system that says yes, rather than no, to children when they ask for help.Dr Max Davie, from the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, said: Education around issues like appearance, gender stereotypes and sexuality is also desperately needed and should be included in the new relationships and sex education curriculum.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lamborghini driver supercar toddington services west end parking
story: The pricey motor was pictured at Toddington Services in Bedfordshire yesterday afternoon just hours before Middle Eastern billionaires brought the West End to a standstill with their vehicles.A mum-of-one, who asked not be named, branded the parking absolutely ridiculous and said it forced her to park further from the services with her newborn baby.The 32-year-old, of Lewisham, South East London, told the Sun Online: Its absolutely ridiculous parking.The services and car park were really busy as it was a bank holiday and spaces were really at a premium.It was really annoying to see how this car was parked.People were driving round trying to find somewhere to park and whoever owned this car clearly didnt car about anyone else.The selfish driver had dumped the fancy car right outside the entrance to the services forcing me to park further away and I had to carry my 10-week-old daughter who was screaming her head off. The kings of bling lit up London’s streets with their flashy motors as a convoy of supercars worth millions drove through the capital.Regent Street is no stranger to a Ferrari or two but over the Bank Holiday Middle Eastern drivers took the phrase “if you’ve got it flaunt it” to a new level.Eye-catching motors in lime green, white, orange and black were driven at a snail’s pace through some of the city’s most exclusives areas.More than a dozen supercars including Lamborghinis, Ferraris, BMWs and even a Bentley Mulsanne worth £230,000 were spotted on the streets of London’s busiest shopping district.Drivers lapped up the attention as crowds of car lovers and shoppers gazed open-mouthed at the luxury cars.The tradition takes place every summer with Middle Eastern motorists shelling out thousands to fly their cars over.Super cars from the likes of Saudi Arabia, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates as well as Kuwait can all be seen parked up in the car parks of the capital’s luxury hotels at the beginning of August.As well countless parking tickets, flashy motorists also have to shell out a fortune to bring their expensive toys over to the UK.But the season soon turns into a godsend for traffic wardens with many left up on double yellows outside some of Londons poshest shops as drivers become frustrated with our packed streets. It costs around £20,000 for a return journey, with airlines like Qatar Airways delivering the motors from Doha to Heathrow.Qatar Airways straps the cars to the floor for the journey and offers places for 31 cars on each flight.Emirates is another airline to offer the service of bringing cars over from the Middle East to the UK.

title: elon musk british cave hero vern unsworth paedo again
story: The businessman was forced to apologise following his outrageous remarks about Vern Unsworth last month.But he has taken to Twitter again, this time to question why diver Vern hasnt sued him in wake of the remarks.He wrote: You don’t think it’s strange he hasn’t sued me? He was offered free legal services.In a tense Twitter exchange with a journalist he added: Did you investigate at all? I’m guessing answer is no. Why?Shares in his company dived by around £2billion following his initial comments, which he now admits were made in anger.He tweeted an apology: “My words were spoken in anger after Mr. Unsworth said several untruths &amp suggested I engage in a sexual act with the mini-sub, which had been built as an act of kindness &amp according to specifications from the dive team leader.“Nonetheless, his actions against me do not justify my actions against him, and for that I apologize to Mr. Unsworth and to the companies I represent as leader. The fault is mine and mine alone.Unsworth is a British expat and caver who lives near the Tham Luang tunnel network where the 12 boys and their football coach were trapped for more than two weeks.He was scathing of Musks offer to send a mini-submarine to help in the rescue efforts, which he dismissed as just a PR stunt and said the billionaire could stick the submarine where it hurts.Musk - worth a reported 20bn-  then hit back in a bizarre series of tweets, some of which he later deleted, suggesting the expert had exaggerated his role in the rescue.Musk had claimed it was suspicious the 63-year-old lived in Thailand before explicitly branding him a paedo in one post.Musk added: Never saw this British expat guy who lives in Thailand  at any point when we were in the caves.Unsworth had said he was considering taking legal action against Musk for his astonishing remarks.Last month Unsworth said: Ive been approached by British lawyers, American lawyers. I havent decided what to do next yet.I cant let it go. Theres too much out there already, Unsworth told Reuters in an interview.Asked why he thought Musk would make such a comment about him, he said: I dont know.

title: twins sold online brit couple judith alan kilshaw starting university america
story: Kiara and Keyara Wecker were just six months old when they were handed over for £8,200 to Judith and Alan Kilshaw back in 2001.The Sun exclusively revealed the story after the girls were taken back to Buckley, North Wales by the couple.But despite a seemingly happy ending with their new solicitor parents - the tots were plunged into a grim fight for their custody.It was sensationally revealed that their birth mum Tranda Wecker had previously sold them to another set of parents back in the US.The twins were first bought for £4,000 by Californians Richard and Vickie Allen, who began to raise them as their own.But two months later they were snatched back by their mum and sold for twice as much to Brits Alan and Judith.The two families both then claimed the tots were theirs and were at war over the girls future.The babies - named Belinda and Kimberley by the Kilshaws - were brought into Britain on holiday visas and their new parents were made wards of the court by their council in North Wales.However, following the involvement of the FBI, a trans-Atlantic legal battle was launched and the girls were eventually returned the States where they were found a new foster family in Missouri.The Daily Mirror reports the flourishing girls  - now 18  and living under new names - are studying social sciences at a university in the U.S.Their adoptive mum told the paper how they have grown into fine young women, each with their own dreams and ambitions.She said: At times it has been tough, sure it has, but they are our babies and we cannot be more proud of them.Their adoptive dad, 72, told the Mirror: I felt it was my duty to take them. They brought them straight from the airport to our home and we have never looked back since.According to their adoptive parents, the girls are allowed to meet their birth mum but do not want to.They grew up playing sports, including lacrosse and basketball, and are now playing in their university band.The girls enjoy similar interests, but Keyara is described as outgoing while Kiara is more shy.The sisters live at home with their adoptive family but are hoping to move out soon.

title: goats prefer smiling human faces to grumpy ones study finds
story: Dr Alan McElligott, who led the study, said it has "important implications for how we interact with livestock and other species, because the abilities of animals to perceive human emotions might be widespread and not just limited to pets".The study was conducted at the Buttercups Sanctuary for Goats in Kent, and involved researchers showing goats unfamiliar grey-scale faces of the same person - one smiling and one frowning.According to the team, the happy faces got greater interactions from the goats, who were more eager to approach and explore the images with their snouts.Curiously, this was even more likely when the happy faces were positioned on the right of the test arena.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"The paper's first author, Dr Christian Nawroth, said: "We already knew that goats are very attuned to human body language, but we did not know how they react to different human emotional expressions, such as anger and happiness."Here, we show for the first time that goats do not only distinguish between these expressions, but they also prefer to interact with happy ones."The researchers believe their work has implications for understanding how animals process human emotions and facial cues.One of the co-authors, Natalia Albuquerque, said: "The study of emotion perception has already shown very complex abilities in dogs and horses.
